summary: This document is a compilation of FBI 302 reports from the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein (Case 72-MM-113327). It includes interviews with a former Epstein house manager who provided detailed allegations of sexual abuse of minors, the seizure of a 'black book' and notes, and the arrest of an individual for obstruction of justice. The reports detail the witness's observations and the financial and logistical operations supporting the abuse.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the investigation. Described as having sexual contact with minor females at his Palm Beach residence, with his house manager observing evidence and facilitating payments.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Instructed the house manager not to discuss events at Epstein's home and directed him on making payments to girls.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.context: An attorney whom the house manager attempted to sell the seized 'black book' and notes to for $50,000.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: An attorney who contacted the house manager offering legal representation after the manager received a subpoena in civil litigation.

persons.name: Jean Luc Brunel
persons.context: Reported to bring girls to Epstein's house and arrange for their travel via commercial and private planes.

persons.name: Jerome Pierre
persons.context: The gardener at Epstein's Palm Beach property, who the house manager believed was aware of the sexual activity with young girls.

persons.name: Julio Cesar Suarez
persons.role: Friend of a witness, Kitchen cabinet salesperson
persons.context: Interviewed by the FBI. He was with a friend (the house manager) when documents related to Epstein were brought to a Hilton Hotel, but he denied knowledge of the documents' contents.

persons.name: Linnea R. Johnson
persons.context: Issued an arrest warrant for Obstruction of Justice related to the Epstein investigation.

connections.description: Maxwell instructed Epstein's staff on payments to girls and told them not to discuss activities at the home.
Brunel brought girls to Epstein's house and arranged their travel.
Pierre was the gardener at Epstein's Palm Beach property and was believed to be aware of the sexual activity.
Epstein's former house manager attempted to sell evidence (the 'black book') to attorney Edwards.
After the house manager alerted Epstein's organization about a subpoena, attorney Goldberger contacted him offering representation.

events.title: Seizure of Black Book and Notes
events.description: FBI agents seized a black bound book and handwritten notes from Epstein's former house manager during an interview in Boca Raton, Florida.

events.title: Consent Search of Vehicle
events.description: A witness (likely the house manager) consented to a search of his vehicle (a Chevrolet Trailblazer) and cellular phones.

events.title: Interview of Julio Cesar Suarez
events.description: FBI interviewed Julio Cesar Suarez at the Hilton Hotel in Boca Raton. He was with the house manager when documents were brought to the hotel but denied knowledge of them.

events.title: Arrest for Obstruction of Justice
events.description: An individual (name redacted) was arrested pursuant to a warrant issued by Judge Linnea R. Johnson for Obstruction of Justice (18 U.S.C. 1512).

events.title: House Manager's Employment Period
events.description: The key witness worked as a house manager for Jeffrey Epstein for approximately six months, during which he observed and facilitated activities related to the abuse of minors.

locations: Belvedere Road and U.S. Highway 1, Palm Beach county
keyFacts: A former Epstein house manager provided the FBI with a 'black book' containing contact information for individuals, many of whom he claimed were underage females, which he had attempted to sell to attorney Bradley Edwards for $50,000.

The house manager described observing naked underage girls at Epstein's pool, pornographic images on computers, and being tasked with cleaning sex toys and used condoms after massages, which occurred twice daily.
The witness stated Ghislaine Maxwell instructed him not to discuss what occurred at Epstein's home and directed him on making cash payments to girls, funds which Epstein would withdraw from the bank.
Jean Luc Brunel was identified as bringing girls to Epstein's house and arranging their travel via commercial and private planes.
An individual was arrested on December 8, 2009, for Obstruction of Justice in connection with the Epstein investigation.
